lines.content: AI Tools Used: ChatGPT, Stack Overflow & AI Summarization
Purpose: Javadoc improvements, Bug fixing, Code refactoring, Researching common issues
* Significantly improved the quality of Javadoc documentation by making it clearer, more concise, and standardized across the codebase
* Streamlined redundant code and improved readability
This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/nat.Duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run nat.Duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.

Welcome to **Nat**, a task management chatbot that helps you organize your tasks efficiently through a GUI interface.
Adds a simple task without a deadline.
Adds a task with a specific deadline.
✅ *Adds "Submit report", due on December 5, 2034, at 6:00 PM.*
Adds a task with a start and end time.
✅ *Adds "Attend AI workshop" from 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM on June 10, 2025.*
Here are the tasks in your list:
3. [E][ ] Attend AI workshop (from: Jun 10 2025, 9:00 AM to: Jun 10 2025, 5:00 PM)
Removes a task from the list.
2. [E][ ] Attend AI workshop (from: Jun 10 2025, 9:00 AM to: Jun 10 2025, 5:00 PM)
- Tasks are **automatically saved** when you exit.
| `unmark <task_number>` | Marks a task as not done |
assertEquals(0, taskList.getTaskList().size(), "Task list should remain empty if command has no description.");
assertFalse(taskList.getTaskList().get(0).isDone(), "Task should be marked as not done.");
assertEquals(0, taskList.getTaskList().size(), "Task list should be empty after deleting the only task.");
package nat; //same package as the class being tested
ToDo task = new ToDo("Read a book");
* Represents a task with a specific deadline.
* This class extends {@link Task} and includes a {@link LocalDateTime} field
* to store the due date of the task.
* Creates a new Deadline task with the given name and due date.
* @param taskName The name of the task.
* @param dueDate  The deadline of the task in {@code "d/M/yyyy HHmm"} format (e.g., "2/12/2019 1800").
* Parses a date-time string and converts it into a {@link LocalDateTime} object.
* The expected input format is {@code "d/M/yyyy HHmm"} (e.g., "2/12/2019 1800").
* @param dateTime The date-time string to be parsed.
* @return A {@link LocalDateTime} representation of the input.
* Converts the Deadline task into a formatted string for storage.
* - Due date is formatted as {@code "d/M/yyyy HHmm"} (e.g., "2/12/2019 1800").
* @return A formatted string representing the Deadline task in storage format.
* Returns the task type identifier for Deadline tasks.
* @return The character {@code "D"} representing a Deadline task.
* Returns a string representation of the Deadline task,
* including its completion status, task name, and formatted due date.
* The due date is displayed in {@code "MMM dd yyyy, h:mm a"} format (e.g., "Dec 02 2019, 6:00 PM").
* @return A formatted string representing the Deadline task.
DateTimeFormatter outputFormat = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM dd yyyy, h:mm a");
* Represents a dialog box containing an image and a label displaying text.
* This is used to show conversations between the user and the chatbot.
* Constructs a DialogBox with the specified text, image, and alignment.
* @param text   The text to display in the dialog box.
* @param img    The image representing the speaker.
* @param isUser {@code true} if the dialog belongs to the user, {@code false} if it belongs to the chatbot.
* @param isError {@code true} if the message represents an error response.
private DialogBox(String text, Image img, boolean isUser, boolean isError) {
* Flips the dialog box so that the image appears on the left and text on the right.
* Used to differentiate between user and chatbot messages.
* Creates a dialog box representing a user message.
* @param text The text entered by the user.
* @return A styled {@code DialogBox} representing the user's message.
public static DialogBox getUserDialog(String text, Image img) {
return new DialogBox(text, img, true, false);
* Creates a dialog box representing a response from the chatbot.
* @return A styled {@code DialogBox} representing the chatbot's response.
public static DialogBox getNatDialog(String text, Image img) {
var db = new DialogBox(text, img, false, false);
public static DialogBox getErrorDialog(String text, Image img) {
var db = new DialogBox(text, img, false, true);
* Represents an event task with a start date and an end date.
* This class extends {@link Task} and includes two {@link LocalDateTime} fields
* to store the start time and due date of the task.
* Creates a new Event task with the given name, start date, and due date.
* @param taskName  The name of the task.
* @param startDate The start date of the event in {@code "d/M/yyyy HHmm"} format (e.g., "2/12/2019 1400").
* @param dueDate   The due date of the event in {@code "d/M/yyyy HHmm"} format (e.g., "2/12/2019 1800").
public Event(String taskName, String startDate, String dueDate) {
* Parses a date-time string and converts it into a {@link LocalDateTime} object.
* The expected input format is {@code "d/M/yyyy HHmm"} (e.g., "2/12/2019 1800").
* @param dateTime The date-time string to be parsed.
* @return A {@link LocalDateTime} representation of the input.
* Converts the Event task into a formatted string for storage.
* - Start and due dates are formatted as {@code "d/M/yyyy HHmm"} (e.g., "2/12/2019 1400").
* @return A formatted string representing the Event task in storage format.
* Returns the task type identifier for Event tasks.
* @return The character {@code "E"} representing an Event task.
* Returns a string representation of the Event task,
* including its completion status, task name, and formatted start and due dates.
* The dates are displayed in {@code "MMM dd yyyy, h:mm a"} format (e.g., "Dec 02 2019, 2:00 PM").
* @return A formatted string representing the Event task.
DateTimeFormatter outputFormat = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM dd yyyy, h:mm a");
* A launcher class that serves as an entry point for starting the application.
* This class is required to work around JavaFX classpath issues when packaging the application into a JAR file.
* The {@code Application.launch()} method is called here instead of directly in {@link Main}, ensuring compatibility
* when running JavaFX applications in certain environments.
* The main method that starts the JavaFX application.
* Calls {@link Application#launch(Class, String...)} with {@link Main} as the primary class.
* The main JavaFX application class for Nat.
* This class initializes the graphical user interface (GUI) using FXML and manages the main window.
* It extends {@link Application}, making it the entry point for launching the JavaFX GUI.
* Starts the JavaFX application and sets up the main GUI window.
* @param stage The primary stage for the application window.
* Saves tasks before the application exits.
* This method ensures that any changes made to the task list are stored before the program closes.
* Manages user interactions, message handling, and chatbot responses.
* Initializes the GUI by binding the scroll pane to automatically scroll to the latest message.
* Injects the Nat instance and displays a welcome message.
// Return welcome message after Nat is initialized

* Handles user input by creating two dialog boxes:
* one displaying the user's message and another showing the chatbot's response.
* The user input field is cleared after processing.
* If the user enters "bye", the application saves tasks and exits.

* The core class for the Nat chatbot, responsible for task management and command execution.
* This class initializes essential components such as storage and the task list.
* Initializes the Nat chatbot, loading stored tasks and preparing for user interaction.
* The task list is retrieved from persistent storage.
* An assertion is used to ensure that the task list is not null after initialization.
// Assertion: TaskList should never be null after initialization
assert this.taskList != null : "TaskList should not be null!";
* Processes and executes the given command string.

* If the command is unrecognized, an error message is returned.

* @return A response message indicating the result of the command execution.
return "Oh no! I do not understand that command; please try again!";

return (isDone ? "X" : " "); // mark done task with X
